CSS Fundamentals

Thing Learned / Refreshed

  • Margins collapse into each other when they touch. The biggest value fills the space. So, if the first child in an element has margin-top, that element can merge with the parent's margin-top.
  • Links - ALWAYS include :focus and :hover states
  • Link states. Declaration order matters. Don't overwrite the style you want.
    1. visited
    2. focus
    3. hover
    4. active
  • Links - ALWAYS apply styling to the button/link itself. NOT the paragraph or div container. Make sure that the whole element, padding and all are clickable.
    <a class="button" href="#">contact me</a>
    NOT:
    <div class="button"><a href="#">contact me</a></div>
  • Button styling - use a padding ratio of
    1:2 or 1:2.5 top & bottom to left & right. button
    padding: 1em 2em;
  • Use inline-block to account for margin & padding that wont disrupt the flow of other elements or overtake them.
    display: inline-block;
  • One <h1> per page
  • Specificity Power:
    • 0,0,1 - element
    • 0,1,0 - class / attribute / pseudo
    • 1,0,0 - id
    • ‚ö°Ô∏è,‚ö°Ô∏è,‚ö°Ô∏è - inline style (the emperor)
    • üí•,üí•,üí• - !important (the deathstar)

Search Bar - Step One

.includes()
.toLowerCase()

The addEventListener() method attaches an event handler to the specified element

addEventListener() has a second parameter of 'function', which gives us an 'event', which inside has lots of properties and methods

We can use the property of 'target' which returns the element that triggered the event

The 'event.target' has another property called 'value', so 'event.target.value' which in the case of our input box, gives us the value the user typed in!

                
const usernameInput = document.getElementById('usernameInput')

usernameInput.addEventListener('keyup', function(event){
    let username = event.target.value.toLowerCase()
    console.log(username)
})

event is the function's parameter. On its own, without the target or value, it is simply the KeyboardEvent.

Search Bar - Step Two

Don't get confused between .textContent and .value

Remember to use .length when using a loop

The .includes() method determines whether one string may be found within another string, returning true or false as appropriate. MDN

                
const sentence = 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.';

const word = 'fox';

console.log(`The word "${word}" ${sentence.includes(word) ? 'is' : 'is not'} in the sentence`);
// expected output: "The word "fox" is in the sentence"

const searchInput = document.getElementById("searchInput")

searchInput.addEventListener("keyup", function(event) {
  // at each keyup event, the target input's value
  // is set lower case. The *searchQuery* variable 
  // changes on every keyup.
  let searchQuery = event.target.value.toLowerCase();
  // get HTMLCollection
  let allNamesDOMCollection = document.getElementsByClassName('name');
  
  for (let i = 0; i < allNamesDOMCollection.length; i++) {
    // set each name to lowercase
    const currentName = allNamesDOMCollection[i].textContent.toLowerCase();
    // conditional, does indexed name include any of searchQuery? 
    if(currentName.includes(searchQuery.toLowerCase())){
        allNamesDOMCollection[i].style.display = 'block'
    } else {
        allNamesDOMCollection[i].style.display = 'none'
    }
  }
});

Carousel - Step Three

for...of
classList.add()
classList.remove()
                
const slides = document.getElementsByClassName('carousel-item');
let slidePosition = 0;
const totalSlides = slides.length;

document.getElementById('carousel-button-next').addEventListener('click', moveToNextSlide);
document.getElementById('carousel-button-prev').addEventListener('click', moveToPrevSlide);

function hideAllSlides() {
    // set all slides to hidden
    for(let slide of slides){
        slide.classList.remove("carousel-item-visible")
        slide.classList.add("carousel-item-hidden")
    }
}

function moveToNextSlide() {
  // call straight away
  hideAllSlides()
  
  // conditional, are we on the last slide?
  if (slidePosition === totalSlides - 1) {
    // yes? then reset to the first slide
    slidePosition = 0;
  } else {
    //no? then move to the next slide
    slidePosition++;
  }
  // show the slide we're on
  slides[slidePosition].classList.add("carousel-item-visible");
}
                
              
                
.carousel .carousel-item,
.carousel .carousel-item-hidden {
    display: none;
}

The carousel items have display none property by default but also have it as a separate 'hidden' class.

Use a for...of to loop through the slides and hide them all.

On each button, firstly, hide all the slides. Then check what slide we're on with a conditional.

Remember zero indexing.
.length will give you 1-3. An array gives you 0-2. Thats why we have totalSlides -1.

Carousel - Step Four

                
const slides = document.getElementsByClassName('carousel-item');
let slidePosition = 0;
const totalSlides = slides.length;

document.getElementById('carousel-button-next').addEventListener('click', moveToNextSlide);
document.getElementById('carousel-button-prev').addEventListener('click', moveToPrevSlide);

function hideAllSlides() {
    for (let slide of slides) {
        slide.classList.remove('carousel-item-visible');
        slide.classList.add('carousel-item-hidden');
    }
}

function moveToNextSlide() {
  // call straight away
  hideAllSlides()
  // conditional, are we on the last slide?
  if (slidePosition === totalSlides - 1) {
    // yes? then reset to the first slide
    slidePosition = 0;
  } else {
    //no? then move to the next slide
    slidePosition++;
  }
  // show the slide we're on
  slides[slidePosition].classList.add("carousel-item-visible");
}

function moveToPrevSlide() {
    hideAllSlides();
    // condition are we on the first slide?
    if (slidePosition === 0) {
      // yes? then reset to the last slide
      slidePosition = totalSlides - 1;
    } else {
      // no? then move back to the last slide
      slidePosition--;
    }
    
  slides[slidePosition].classList.add("carousel-item-visible");
}

Dice Game

!
Math.random
Things Learned
  • Use true and false values to determine who's turn it is.
  • Initialize a variable by setting it to true:
    let player1Turn = true
  • Use true and false values as a switch with the ! not operator.
    Instead of a lengthy if/else statement, set a true value to false like this:
    player1Turn = !player1Turn
  • A const inside a function will reset when the function is called. It will still not be mutable inside the function.
  • Math 
                    
const randomNumber = 
  Math.floor(Math.random() * 6) + 1
  //          0-1         0-5    1-6

  • let variables for scores and true/false values
  • const variables for grabbed document elements
  • Reverse psychology. On players turn switch, update the opposite player.

// Create variables for the game state
let player1Score = 0
let player2Score = 0
let player1Turn = true

// Create variables to store references to the necessary DOM nodes
const player1Dice = document.getElementById("player1Dice")
const player2Dice = document.getElementById("player2Dice")
const player1Scoreboard = document.getElementById("player1Scoreboard")
const player2Scoreboard = document.getElementById("player2Scoreboard")
const message = document.getElementById("message")
const rollBtn = document.getElementById("rollBtn")
const resetBtn = document.getElementById("resetBtn")

// Flip button
function showResetButton() {
    rollBtn.style.display = "none"
    resetBtn.style.display = "block"
}

/* Hook up a click event listener to the Roll Dice Button. */
rollBtn.addEventListener("click", function() {
  const randomNumber = Math.floor(Math.random() * 6) + 1

  if (player1Turn) {
    player1Score += randomNumber
    player1Scoreboard.textContent = player1Score
    player1Dice.textContent = randomNumber
    player1Dice.classList.remove("active")
    player2Dice.classList.add("active")
    message.textContent = "Player 2 Turn"
  } else {
    player2Score += randomNumber
    player2Scoreboard.textContent = player2Score
    player2Dice.textContent = randomNumber
    player2Dice.classList.remove("active")
    player1Dice.classList.add("active")
    message.textContent = "Player 1 Turn"
  }
  
  if (player1Score >= 20) {
    message.textContent = "Player 1 Won ü•≥"
    showResetButton()
  } else if (player2Score >= 20) {
    message.textContent = "Player 2 Won üéâ"
    showResetButton()
  }
  // Flip turn true, false, true, false, true.....etc.
  player1Turn = !player1Turn
})

// reset the board 
resetBtn.addEventListener("click", function(){
    reset()
})

function reset() {
    player1Score = 0
    player2Score = 0
    player1Turn = true
    player1Scoreboard.textContent = 0
    player2Scoreboard.textContent = 0
    player1Dice.textContent = "-"
    player2Dice.textContent = "-"
    message.textContent = "Player 1 Turn"
    resetBtn.style.display = "none"
    rollBtn.style.display = "block"
    player2Dice.classList.remove("active")
    player1Dice.classList.add("active")
}

Generate Grid

Generate a grid of exactly 0-99 squares with a for loop.

                
function createGrid() {
  //create 100 of these elements with a for loop
  for (let i=0; i < width*width; i++) {
  //create element
  const square = document.createElement('div')
  //add styling to the element
  square.classList.add('square')
  //put the element into our grid
  grid.appendChild(square)
  //push it into a new squares array    
  squares.push(square)
  }
}

Create Snake / Movement

Give the illusion of movement by taking the snake's tail and adding it to the front.

Make this easier to handle by reversing the snake's array. That way currentSnake[0] is always the head.

                
let currentSnake = [2,1,0]
let direction = 1

// create snake
currentSnake.forEach(index => squares[index].classList.add('snake'))

function move() {
  //remove last element from our currentSnake array
  const tail = currentSnake.pop()
  //remove styling from last element
  squares[tail].classList.remove('snake')
  //add square in direction we are heading
  currentSnake.unshift(currentSnake[0] + direction)
  //add styling so we can see it
  squares[currentSnake[0]].classList.add('snake')
}

// move one block to the right

Key Codes / Movement / Direction

keycode.info

Declare width as a variable. Use this to change the grid size globally in future.

left and right +/- 1 Up and down +/- 10

                
const width = 10                  
                  
function control(e) {
  if (e.keyCode === 39) {
    console.log('right pressed')
    direction = 1
  } else if (e.keyCode === 38) {
    console.log('up pressed')
    direction = -width
  } else if (e.keyCode === 37) {
    console.log('left pressed')
    direction = -1
  } else if (e.keyCode === 40) {
    console.log('down pressed')
    direction = +width
  }
}
document.addEventListener('keydown', control)

Use keydown so direction changes instantly, not on keyup

Timing

timerId is a common variable naming convention. Set an action/function and a duration in milliseconds. That function will keep firing at every interval until stopped by the clearInterval(timerId) being called.

                
let timerId = setInterval(move, 1000)

clearInterval(timerId)

clearInterval(timerId) will be used inside the move function.

Collision Detection

The snake can be on the edge, but can't go past the border.

classList.contains('snake')

From MDM:
The Node.contains() method returns a Boolean value indicating whether a node is a descendant of a given node, i.e. the node itself, one of its direct children (childNodes), one of the children's direct children, and so on.
                
function move() {
  if (
    (currentSnake[0] + width >= width*width && direction === width) || 
    //if snake has hit bottom
    (currentSnake[0] % width === width-1 && direction === 1) || 
    //if snake has hit right wall
    (currentSnake[0] % width === 0 && direction === -1) || 
    //if snake has hit left wall
    (currentSnake[0] - width < 0 && direction === -width) || 
    //if snake has hit top
    squares[currentSnake[0] + direction].classList.contains('snake')
    //if snake has hit itself
  )
  return clearInterval(timerId) // COLLISION! STOP!
  
  //remove last element from our currentSnake array
  const tail = currentSnake.pop()
  //remove styling from last element
  squares[tail].classList.remove('snake')
  //add square in direction we are heading
  currentSnake.unshift(currentSnake[0] + direction)
  //add styling so we can see it
  squares[currentSnake[0]].classList.add('snake')
}
move()

Generate Apples

                
function generateApples() {
  do {
      //generate a random number...
      appleIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * squares.length)
  } while (squares[appleIndex].classList.contains('snake')) 
  // ...while this is true
  // if false (not a snake), add an apple.
  
  squares[appleIndex].classList.add('apple')
}
generateApples()

do... a thing, while... this thing is true.

So, generate a random number between 0-99, while that number/index is a snake square.

If it's not a snake square, (likely) create an apple on the random number square.

If it a snake square, generate another random number

Snake eats and grows

                
//deal with snake head gets apple

    //remove the class of apple

    //grow our snake by adding class of snake to it
    squares[tail].classList.add('snake')

Generate new apple

Multiply the time by 0.9 (shortens the interval) the variable speed

Start/Reset Button

                
function startGame() {
  //remove the snake
  currentSnake.forEach(index => squares[index].classList.remove('snake'))
  //remove the apple
  squares[appleIndex].classList.remove('apple')
  //clear timer
  clearInterval(timerId)
  // reset the snake
  currentSnake = [2,1,0]
  score = 0
  // add new score to browser
  scoreDisplay.textContent = score
  direction = 1
  intervalTime = 1000
  generateApple()
  //read the class of snake to our new currentSnake
  currentSnake.forEach(index => squares[index].classList.add('snake'))
  timerId = setInterval(move, intervalTime)
}

Keep track of the variables

forEach(index, function)
For each part of the current snake, remove its class.

// ---- variables ------------------------------
const grid = document.querySelector('.grid')
const startButton = document.getElementById('start')
const scoreDisplay = document.getElementById('score')
let squares = []
let currentSnake = [2,1,0]
let direction = 1
const width = 10
let appleIndex = 0
let score = 0
let intervalTime = 1000
let speed = 0.9
let timerId = 0

// ---- create grid ------------------------------

function createGrid() {
  //create 100 of these elements with a for loop
  for (let i=0; i < width*width; i++) {
    //create element
  const square = document.createElement('div')
  //add styling to the element
  square.classList.add('square')
  //put the element into our grid
  grid.appendChild(square)
  //push it into a new squares array    
  squares.push(square)
  }
}

createGrid()

// ---- create snake ----------------------------

currentSnake.forEach(index => squares[index].classList.add('snake'))

// ----- reset -----------------------------

function startGame() {
  //remove the snake
  currentSnake.forEach(index => squares[index].classList.remove('snake'))
  //remove the apple
  squares[appleIndex].classList.remove('apple')
  clearInterval(timerId)
  currentSnake = [2,1,0]
  score = 0
  // add new score to browser
  scoreDisplay.textContent = score
  direction = 1
  intervalTime = 1000
  generateApple()
  //read the class of snake to our new currentSnake
  currentSnake.forEach(index => squares[index].classList.add('snake'))
  timerId = setInterval(move, intervalTime)
}

// ------ move ----------------------------

function move() {
  // collision
  if (
    (currentSnake[0] + width >= width*width && direction === width) || //if snake has hit bottom
    (currentSnake[0] % width === width-1 && direction === 1) || //if snake has hit right wall
    (currentSnake[0] % width === 0 && direction === -1) || //if snake has hit left wall
    (currentSnake[0] - width < 0 && direction === -width) || //if snake has hit top
    squares[currentSnake[0] + direction].classList.contains('snake')
  )
  return clearInterval(timerId) // STOP

  
  // -- pop tail, add direction --
  //remove last element from our currentSnake array
  const tail = currentSnake.pop()
  //remove styling from last element
  squares[tail].classList.remove('snake')
  //add square in direction we are heading
  currentSnake.unshift(currentSnake[0] + direction)
  //add styling so we can see it
  
  // -- deal with snake head gets apple --
  if (squares[currentSnake[0]].classList.contains('apple')) {
    //remove the class of apple
    squares[currentSnake[0]].classList.remove('apple')
    //grow our snake by adding class of snake to it
    squares[tail].classList.add('snake')
    console.log(tail)
    //grow our snake array
    currentSnake.push(tail)
    console.log(currentSnake)
    //generate new apple
    generateApple()
    //add one to the score
    score++
    //display our score
    scoreDisplay.textContent = score
    //speed up our snake
    clearInterval(timerId)
    console.log(intervalTime)
    intervalTime = intervalTime * speed
    console.log(intervalTime)
    timerId = setInterval(move, intervalTime)
  }

  squares[currentSnake[0]].classList.add('snake')
}

// ----------------------------------

function generateApple() {
  do {
      appleIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * squares.length)
  } while (squares[appleIndex].classList.contains('snake'))
      squares[appleIndex].classList.add('apple')
}

  } else if (e.keyCode === 38) {

      direction = -width
  } else if (e.keyCode === 37) {
      console.log('left pressed')
      direction = -1
  } else if (e.keyCode === 40) {

      direction = +width
  }
}

Starting to think Responsively

Things Learned / Refreshed

ems are always relative to their parent. Can cause cascading size issues with fonts. Good for padding.

Use rems (root em) to font sizes

                
h1 {
  font-size: 24px;
  margin-bottom: 1em; /* 24 px */
  margin-bottom: 2em; /* 48px */
}

Pixels follow the 'reference pixel' They will be the same on every screen regardless of resolution. Retina displays etc.

95% max-width. Don't hit the edges on smaller screens.

                  
.container {
  widows: 95%;
  max-width: 980px;
  margin: 0 auto;
}

Put a max-width of 100% on images, not just width, so they don't grow beyond their size.

Have an img selector up yop next to the body styles. use display: block; to avoid glippy bottom spacing associated with inline elements. 

                
img {
  max-width: 100%;
  display: block;
}

Also create a one-line container flex style to apply on all flex parent elements.

                
.container-flex {
  display: flex;
}

justification and alignment can be applied ad hoc.

Note on compound selectors

                
/* this is fine */               
nav ul {

}

/*  DON'T DO THIS */
nav ul li {
    
}

/* DON'T DO THIS */
nav ul li a {
    
}

Think about how easy it is to read. Don't add unnecessary specificity.

                             
nav ul {

}

nav li {
    
}

nav a {
    
}

Remove bullet points & default list padding:

                             
ul {
  list-style: none;
  padding: 0;
}

Media Queries

You need a type and/or a condition.

In this below example, the background of the body will only be red when using a device that has a screen, and which has a width of 600px or bigger.

                
/* @media [media type] ([media condition]) { ... } */

@media screen and (min-width: 600px) {
  body {
      background: red;
  }
}

Types

  • all
  • screen
  • print
  • speech
                
header {
  background: #f8f8f8;
  padding: 2em 0;
}

@media (max-width: 675px) {
  .container-flex {
      flex-direction: column;
  }
  
  header {
      text-align: center;
  }
}

Its fine to include media queries after each element that needs them.

                
/* MAX WIDTH - everything up to and including this width */
@media (max-width: 675px) {
}

/* MIN-WIDTH - everything beyond this width */
@media (min-width: 675px) {
}

/* BOTH - everything between */
@media (min-width: 400px) and (max-width: 600px) {
}

MAX & MIN

Order is important!

put bigger size last so they sizes are not overwritten by a smaller size after.

                
/* from a minimum width of 400px and bigger */
@media (min-width: 400px) {
    body {
        background: purple;
    }
}

/* from a minimum width of 650px and bigger */
@media (min-width: 650px) {
    body {
        background: orange;
    }
}

Combine conditions with and

If orientation becomes portrait, the background will revert to pink.

                
body {
  background: pink;
}                  
                  
@media (min-width: 500px) and (orientation: landscape) {
  body {
      background: orange;
  }
}

THE ESSENTIAL META TAG

meta name="" content=""

The meta tag has many uses, but the most important is the 

                
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
  <meta name="author" content="Kevin Powell">
</head>

Always use the meta tag!

This sets the viewport equal to the device's viewport. THIS IS A MUST FOR MOBILES AND TABLETS

Responsive Design Challenges

flex-flow

flex-flow is a shorthand property for direction and/or wrapping.

                
/* flex-flow: <'flex-direction'> */
flex-flow: row;
flex-flow: row-reverse;
flex-flow: column;
flex-flow: column-reverse;

/* flex-flow: <'flex-wrap'> */
flex-flow: nowrap;
flex-flow: wrap;
flex-flow: wrap-reverse;

/* flex-flow: <'flex-direction'> and <'flex-wrap'> */
flex-flow: row nowrap;
flex-flow: column wrap;
flex-flow: column-reverse wrap-reverse;

/* Global values */
flex-flow: inherit;
flex-flow: initial;
flex-flow: unset;
align-items: baseline;

align-items: baseline; will place the first line, of two or more flex columns on the same baseline of text.

Stepping Up Our Style

line-height: aka 'leading'. Keep it about 1.6 on the body text. Use a unit-lessnumber, not ems or px. It will be responsive to the typography its assigned to. line-height is measured as half the font size above and half below. For big text or 'all caps' consider a smaller line-height.

Use text-transform: to capitalize, uppercase or lowercase blocks of type. Keep the html as it is.

letter-spacing: aka 'tracking'. Good for all caps and small text. Use px as a unit. A little goes a long way.

letter-spacing at 5px, transformed to uppercase

background-image:

Use url(../images/picture.png TWO DOTS, TWO STEPS BACK. The default position is to tile.

default top left
                
.bg-image-one {
  background-image: url("https://source.unsplash.com/daily?dark_red");
  background-color: #000;
}

have a fallback background-color in case the image doesn't load.

background-position: center;
                
.bg-image-two {
  background-image: url("https://source.unsplash.com/daily?dark_red");
  background-color: #000;
  background-position: center;
  /* background-position: top left / bottom right; */
}
                
              
                
.bg-image-three {
  background-image: url("https://source.unsplash.com/daily?dark_red");
  background-color: #000;
  background-size: cover;
}

cover: Scales the image as large as possible to fill the container, stretching the image if necessary. If the proportions of the image differ from the element, it is cropped either vertically or horizontally so that no empty space remains.

                
.bg-image-four {
  background-image: url("https://source.unsplash.com/daily?dark_red");
  background-color: #000;
  background-size: contain;
}

contain: Scales the image as large as possible within its container without cropping or stretching the image. If the container is larger than the image, this will result in image tiling, unless the background-repeat property is set to no-repeat.

CSS tricks - Stripes

border image (for border gradients)

                
.border-gradient {
  width: 180px;
  height: 150px;
  border: 20px solid;
  border-image: linear-gradient(45deg, #5eb1bf, #ef7b45) 1;
  /* with a slice value */
}

Border gradients, use border-image. Include a slice value. However, border-radius is impossible this way.

                
.border-gradient2 {
width: 180px;
height: 150px;
border: 20px solid;
border-image: linear-gradient(45deg, #5eb1bf, #ef7b45);
/* with NO slice value (just the four corners)*/
}
                
              
                
.border-gradient3 {
  width: 300px;
  height: 80px;
  border: double 1em transparent;
  border-radius: 30px;
  background-image: linear-gradient(white, white), 
                    linear-gradient(45deg, #5eb1bf, #ef7b45);
  background-origin: border-box;
  background-clip: content-box, border-box;
}

To have gradients on the border and rounded corners, use background-clip: content-box, border-box; and forgo border-image for background-image.

gradient on screen

  background-image: url("https://source.unsplash.com/daily?dark_shark"), linear-gradient(45deg,red, blue);
    /* background-color: #ff0000; */
    background-blend-mode: screen;
    background-size: cover;
    background-position: center;
}

Multiply - Anything lighter than the background color we use will not show through.

Screen - Anything darker than the background color we use will not show through.

Overlay - Anything lighter than the background color will go lighter and the darks will go darker. Loosly Colorizes an image.

}

.btn-primary:hover {
  background-color: #F18119;
}

Put the transition on the element, not its transitioned to state. Keep the duration to 250ms - 500ms. Any more is considered indulgent.

  • property
  • duration ms or s
  • timing-function: ease, ease-in etc
  • delay
                
.btn-scale {
  background-image: linear-gradient(to left, #FF713B, #FFA51D);
  color: white;
  transform: scale(1);
  transition: transform 250ms;
}

.btn-scale:hover,
.btn-scale:active {
  transform: scale(1.1);
}

Set a initial scale value of 1.

IMPORTANT When moving elements with transitions, Don't use top, left, etc positions or -100% margin. Do use translate instead.

Understanding Transitions - the Critical Rendering Path.


Styles > Layout > Paint > Composite

Styles: The browser starts calculating the styles to apply in elements ‚Äî Recalculate Style.

Layout: In the following layer, the browser will start generating the shape and position for each of those elements ‚Äî Layout. This is where the browser sets the page properties such as width and height, as well as its margins, or left/top/right/bottom for instance.

Paint: The browser will now start filling in the pixels for each element into layers. The properties that it uses are, for instance: box-shadow, border-radius, color, background-color, among others.

Composite: This is where you want to do your magic, as this is when the browser starts drawing all the layers in the screen. Modern browsers can animate four styles pretty, pretty well, making use of the transform and opacity properties.

  • Position ‚Äî transform: translateX(n) translateY(n) translateZ(n);
  • Scale ‚Äî transform: scale(n);
  • Rotation ‚Äî transform: rotate(ndeg);
  • Opacity ‚Äî opacity: n;

The transform properties affect a Composite. Here we‚Äôre telling the browser that layers will be painted and ready to go as soon as the animation starts, so there are fewer hiccups when rendering the animation.

More info on the critical rendering path.

let emailCollectorForm = document.getElementById("Email-Collector")
let mainContent = document.getElementById('Main-Content')

emailCollectorForm.addEventListener("submit", event => {
    // Stop the default event behavior
    event.preventDefault()
    
    // use FormData to get the User's name and email 
    // Create a new instance of FormData 
    let ourFormData = new FormData(event.target)
    
    // Get name and email from the FormData
    let userFirstName = ourFormData.get('firstName')    
    let userEmailAddress = ourFormData.get('emailAddress')  
    
    // Create new content  
    let updatedHtmlContent = `
        <h2>Congratulations, ${userFirstName}!</h2>
    
        <p>You're on your way to becoming a BBQ Master!</p>
        
        <p class="fine-print">You will get weekly BBQ tips sent to: ${userEmailAddress}</p>
    `
    //update the content
    mainContent.innerHTML = updatedHtmlContent
})
